elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new luminescent pillared Cerium sulfate–aminodiphosphonate has been prepared and its structure was solved <ce:italic>ab initio</ce:italic> from X-ray powder diffraction data.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para view="all">The inorganic layers are pillared from the bispipiredine groups belonging to the diphosphonic groups, alternating with the sulfate tetrahedra.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new pillared cerium(IV) sulfate–diphosphonate with formula Ce<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)[(O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)–NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N–(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O has been hydrothermally synthesized and its structure has been solved <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic>
<ce:italic>initio</ce:italic> from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new luminescent pillared Cerium sulfate-aminodiphosphonate has been prepared and its structure was solved ab initio from X-ray powder diffraction data.

The inorganic layers are pillared from the bispipiredine groups belonging to the diphosphonic groups, alternating with the sulfate tetrahedra.

Abstract

A new pillared cerium(IV) sulfate-diphosphonate with formula Ce2(2H2O)[(O3PCH2)-NC10H18N-(CH2PO3)(SO4)2]⋅6H2O has been hydrothermally synthesized and its structure has been solved ab initio from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:simple-para view="all">The luminescent and thermal properties of this compound have been preliminarily studied and the encouraging results place it in the field of functional hybrid materials.</ce:simple-para><ce:para view="all">The research field on metal phosphonates has been deeply explored during the last two decades because of the great variety of building blocks available for the preparation of functional materials useful in the field of molecular recognition, gas storage, intercalation chemistry and for their optical and magnetic properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The luminescent and thermal properties of this compound have been preliminarily studied and the encouraging results place it in the field of functional hybrid materials.

The research field on metal phosphonates has been deeply explored during the last two decades because of the great variety of building blocks available for the preparation of functional materials useful in the field of molecular recognition, gas storage, intercalation chemistry and for their optical and magnetic properties .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The combination of a large number of phosphonic groups with divalent and tetravalent transition metals has made the scientific literature on this field more and more rich and still today the research for new functional phosphonates is far from being exhausted.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The combination of a large number of phosphonic groups with divalent and tetravalent transition metals has made the scientific literature on this field more and more rich and still today the research for new functional phosphonates is far from being exhausted.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A survey of the transition metal phosphonates has been presented by Clearfield et al.  whereas the tetravalent metal phosphonates, especially those with α and γ type structure, have been mainly described by Alberti et al. .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A survey of the transition metal phosphonates has been presented by Clearfield et al.  whereas the tetravalent metal phosphonates, especially those with α and γ type structure, have been mainly described by Alberti et al. .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Moreover some new zirconium amino-phosphonates have been recently presented by some of us .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The synthesis of lanthanide phosphonates has drawn the scientist’s attention for their possible optical properties. At the present it exists a large number of lanthanide derivatives obtained using different polyphosphonic and mixed carboxylate–phosphonate groups and their structures and properties has been recently collected in a review from Mao . The reaction of lanthanides with different building blocks containing polydentate phosphonic and/or carboxylic groups has led to a class of layered and open-framework materials with a remarkable high structural variability and with luminescent properties . In that review it has been pointed-out that the number of structurally characterized lanthanide phosphonates is relatively low because of the general high insolubility of these derivatives in water and organic solvents, making difficult the obtainment of single crystals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Moreover some new zirconium amino-phosphonates have been recently presented by some of us .

The synthesis of lanthanide phosphonates has drawn the scientist's attention for their possible optical properties. At the present it exists a large number of lanthanide derivatives obtained using different polyphosphonic and mixed carboxylate-phosphonate groups and their structures and properties has been recently collected in a review from Mao . The reaction of lanthanides with different building blocks containing polydentate phosphonic and/or carboxylic groups has led to a class of layered and open-framework materials with a remarkable high structural variability and with luminescent properties . In that review it has been pointed-out that the number of structurally characterized lanthanide phosphonates is relatively low because of the general high insolubility of these derivatives in water and organic solvents, making difficult the obtainment of single crystals.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The improvements of the X-ray powder diffraction methods for the structural determination of unknown compounds have recently increased the number of characterized microcrystalline compounds and here we present a proof.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The improvements of the X-ray powder diffraction methods for the structural determination of unknown compounds have recently increased the number of characterized microcrystalline compounds and here we present a proof.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The topic of this communication is the preparation, characterization and a preliminary study of the properties of a new pillared cerium(IV) mixed sulfate–amino diphosphonate with formula Ce<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)[(O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)–NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N–(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (hereafter <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) . <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been obtained under hydrothermal conditions as pale-yellow microcrystalline powder starting from Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and N,N′-bisphosphonomethyl bipiperidine acid (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>)</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The topic of this communication is the preparation, characterization and a preliminary study of the properties of a new pillared cerium(IV) mixed sulfate-amino diphosphonate with formula Ce2(2H2O)[(O3PCH2)-NC10H18N-(CH2PO3)(SO4)2]⋅6H2O (hereafter 1) . 1 has been obtained under hydrothermal conditions as pale-yellow microcrystalline powder starting from Ce(SO4)2 ⋅4H2O and N,N'-bisphosphonomethyl bipiperidine acid (see  )

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been solved <ce:italic>ab initio</ce:italic> from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data using the FOX program  and refined with the Rietveld method. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a layered-pillared structure. The layers are made of inorganic layers of Cerium phosphonate–sulfate units covalently pillared by the bipiperidine groups as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 has been solved ab initio from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data using the FOX program  and refined with the Rietveld method. 1 has a layered-pillared structure. The layers are made of inorganic layers of Cerium phosphonate-sulfate units covalently pillared by the bipiperidine groups as shown in  a.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Sulfate groups are placed on the external surface of the sheets whereas the phosphonic tetrahedra are localized inside the layer between the CeO<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> polyhedra.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Within a layer each Ce atom is seven-coordinated with the six oxygen atoms belonging to the PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C and SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> groups. The distances Ce–O are included in the 2.36–2.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å range as reported in similar systems , and one water molecule (Ow2) is placed in bridging mode between two Ce atoms at about 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each tetrahedral phosphonic CPO3 group connects four different Ce atoms. Two oxygen atoms (O_1 and O_2) connect two different Ce atoms in a η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> coordination forming a eight membered (Ce–OPO–Ce)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> squared ring. The third phosphonic oxygen (O_3) connects only one Ce atom. The sulfate group is placed in bridging mode between two different Ce atoms with a Ce–OSO–Ce bond and the other two oxygens point toward the interlayer region. A detail of the connectivity is shown in b. This connectivity is similar to that observed by Wang and co-workers especially for the position of the phosphate and sulfate groups . The bipiperidine groups act as pillars designing rectangular channels of about 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å size calculated from the atomic centers. These channels are filled with six water molecules four of which interact via H-bonds with the O atoms of the sulfate groups (S1–O3⋯Ow5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.78<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Sulfate groups are placed on the external surface of the sheets whereas the phosphonic tetrahedra are localized inside the layer between the CeO7 polyhedra.

Within a layer each Ce atom is seven-coordinated with the six oxygen atoms belonging to the PO3C and SO4 groups. The distances Ce-O are included in the 2.36-2.90Å range as reported in similar systems , and one water molecule (Ow2) is placed in bridging mode between two Ce atoms at about 2.5Å. Each tetrahedral phosphonic CPO3 group connects four different Ce atoms. Two oxygen atoms (O_1 and O_2) connect two different Ce atoms in a η2 coordination forming a eight membered (Ce-OPO-Ce)2 squared ring. The third phosphonic oxygen (O_3) connects only one Ce atom. The sulfate group is placed in bridging mode between two different Ce atoms with a Ce-OSO-Ce bond and the other two oxygens point toward the interlayer region. A detail of the connectivity is shown in b. This connectivity is similar to that observed by Wang and co-workers especially for the position of the phosphate and sulfate groups . The bipiperidine groups act as pillars designing rectangular channels of about 8×6Å size calculated from the atomic centers. These channels are filled with six water molecules four of which interact via H-bonds with the O atoms of the sulfate groups (S1-O3⋯Ow5=2.78Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The presence of the sulfate groups, that are placed in an alternating fashion with the diphosphonic groups, make possible the formation of the intralayer channels. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor> shows the structure of the layer perpendicularly to the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis: each sulfate group is surrounded by four R-groups (grey balls) in a squared environment with a geometrical area of about 49<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (calculated without taking account of Van der Waals radii).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The presence of the sulfate groups, that are placed in an alternating fashion with the diphosphonic groups, make possible the formation of the intralayer channels.   shows the structure of the layer perpendicularly to the b-axis: each sulfate group is surrounded by four R-groups (grey balls) in a squared environment with a geometrical area of about 49Å2 (calculated without taking account of Van der Waals radii).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Concerning pillared diphosphonates, previous works demonstrated that the ordered stacking of identical biphosphonic groups generally give close packed compounds with a high density of organic moieties in the interlayer region and therefore without an open-framework structure .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Concerning pillared diphosphonates, previous works demonstrated that the ordered stacking of identical biphosphonic groups generally give close packed compounds with a high density of organic moieties in the interlayer region and therefore without an open-framework structure .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For example the zirconium phenyldiphosphonate is a pillared compound in which the organic groups connect adjacent layers of Zr phosphonate with α- type structure: the interlayer region is fully occupied by the phenyl rings that are placed near to each other, and therefore no space is available .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For example the zirconium phenyldiphosphonate is a pillared compound in which the organic groups connect adjacent layers of Zr phosphonate with α- type structure: the interlayer region is fully occupied by the phenyl rings that are placed near to each other, and therefore no space is available .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A way to give rise to free space in the interlayer region consisted in using large groups like phosphonic pillars alternating with little groups like the phosphite or the phosphate groups . The contemporary presence of large and small groups created a microporosity because the small groups acted as spacers inside the layer. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the sulfate group plays the role fulfilled by the phosphates and phosphites in Zr(IV) pillared diphosphonates compounds. However, differently from the cited examples, in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the sulfate groups are orderly distributed allowing the crystal structure from X-ray powder data to be determined.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A way to give rise to free space in the interlayer region consisted in using large groups like phosphonic pillars alternating with little groups like the phosphite or the phosphate groups . The contemporary presence of large and small groups created a microporosity because the small groups acted as spacers inside the layer. In 1 the sulfate group plays the role fulfilled by the phosphates and phosphites in Zr(IV) pillared diphosphonates compounds. However, differently from the cited examples, in 1 the sulfate groups are orderly distributed allowing the crystal structure from X-ray powder data to be determined.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The thermal behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been studied by coupling thermogravimetric and thermodiffractometric analyses.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The coupled TG-DTA analysis (see S.I.) shows that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, dried for 3 days over 75 R.H. NaCl, loses all the water molecules in the range 25–150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The initial weight loss (14.3%) can be ascribed to the loss of the eight water molecules (calc. 14.8%)</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The thermal behavior of 1 has been studied by coupling thermogravimetric and thermodiffractometric analyses.

The coupled TG-DTA analysis (see S.I.) shows that compound 1, dried for 3 days over 75 R.H. NaCl, loses all the water molecules in the range 25-150°C. The initial weight loss (14.3%) can be ascribed to the loss of the eight water molecules (calc. 14.8%)

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A plateau is then observed between 170 and 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and it should correspond to the formation of the anhydrous phase.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Between 320 and 500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C a second weight loss (calc. 21.3%, obs. 22%) is observed and it corresponds to the combustion of the organic part. The third weight loss of about 7% is observed in 650–780<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C temperature range and it should correspond to the sublimation of the sulfate groups, probably as SO<ce:inf loc="post">2.</ce:inf>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
A plateau is then observed between 170 and 320°C and it should correspond to the formation of the anhydrous phase.

Between 320 and 500°C a second weight loss (calc. 21.3%, obs. 22%) is observed and it corresponds to the combustion of the organic part. The third weight loss of about 7% is observed in 650-780°C temperature range and it should correspond to the sublimation of the sulfate groups, probably as SO2.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The temperature dependent X-ray analysis (TDXD), 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, has been carried out in the 25–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C temperature range and it shows as the framework remains stable and rigid after the solvent removal, apart a general crystallinity loss.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependent X-ray analysis (TDXD),  , has been carried out in the 25-200°C temperature range and it shows as the framework remains stable and rigid after the solvent removal, apart a general crystallinity loss.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is excited by wavelengths longer than 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> ions; Ce<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320°C.

Compound 1, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in   (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with λ <300nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If 1 is excited by wavelengths longer than 300nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for 1, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce4+ ions; Ce3+ ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138cm-1) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480cm-1) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The two kinds of emission shown by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have different lifetimes. In the inset of , the lifetime distributions determined by fitting the emission decay kinetics through the Maximum Entropy method  are displayed. The CT band has a broad distribution of lifetimes ranging from tens up to tenths of nanoseconds with three main peaks at 10.3, 3.7 and 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns, in agreement with the three-exponential function used to fit the luminescence decay through the least-squared analysis. On the other hand, the emission due to the diphosphonic ligand has a more restricted distribution of lifetimes, of biexponential character with two peaks at 0.4 and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns as lifetimes, in agreement with the least-squared analysis .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two kinds of emission shown by 1 have different lifetimes. In the inset of , the lifetime distributions determined by fitting the emission decay kinetics through the Maximum Entropy method  are displayed. The CT band has a broad distribution of lifetimes ranging from tens up to tenths of nanoseconds with three main peaks at 10.3, 3.7 and 0.15ns, in agreement with the three-exponential function used to fit the luminescence decay through the least-squared analysis. On the other hand, the emission due to the diphosphonic ligand has a more restricted distribution of lifetimes, of biexponential character with two peaks at 0.4 and 2ns as lifetimes, in agreement with the least-squared analysis .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In conclusion it is remarkable that, to the best of our knowledge, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents the first example of mixed sulfate–phosphonate in which the well ordered position of the sulfate groups play an important role in designing the open-framework structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion it is remarkable that, to the best of our knowledge, 1 represents the first example of mixed sulfate-phosphonate in which the well ordered position of the sulfate groups play an important role in designing the open-framework structure.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The thermal stability and rigidity together with the optical properties make this material a good example of a multifunctional hybrid material.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Finally the structural determination of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> from laboratory powder diffraction data demonstrates the potential of this technique for structural investigations of insoluble compounds or for studies when single crystals are not available.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The thermal stability and rigidity together with the optical properties make this material a good example of a multifunctional hybrid material.

Finally the structural determination of 1 from laboratory powder diffraction data demonstrates the potential of this technique for structural investigations of insoluble compounds or for studies when single crystals are not available.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CCDC 713945 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2009.02.025" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2009.02.025</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

CCDC 713945 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2009.02.025.

</ce:e-component>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">The phosphonic acid with formula (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)-NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with 0.328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

   Supplementary material  Crystallographic data.     

The phosphonic acid with formula (H2O3PCH2)-NC10H18N-(CH2PO3H2), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound 1 was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404g of Ce(SO4)2 ⋅4H2O (1mmol) with 0.328g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1mmol) in 25ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:e-component>
<ce:label>Supplementary material</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Crystallographic data.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="mmc1"></ce:link>
</ce:e-component>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">The phosphonic acid with formula (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)-NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with 0.328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

   Supplementary material  Crystallographic data.     

The phosphonic acid with formula (H2O3PCH2)-NC10H18N-(CH2PO3H2), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound 1 was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404g of Ce(SO4)2 ⋅4H2O (1mmol) with 0.328g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1mmol) in 25ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The thermal behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been studied by coupling thermogravimetric and thermodiffractometric analyses.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The coupled TG-DTA analysis (see S.I.) shows that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, dried for 3 days over 75 R.H. NaCl, loses all the water molecules in the range 25–150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The initial weight loss (14.3%) can be ascribed to the loss of the eight water molecules (calc. 14.8%)</ce:para><ce:para view="all">A plateau is then observed between 170 and 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and it should correspond to the formation of the anhydrous phase.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Between 320 and 500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C a second weight loss (calc. 21.3%, obs. 22%) is observed and it corresponds to the combustion of the organic part. The third weight loss of about 7% is observed in 650–780<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C temperature range and it should correspond to the sublimation of the sulfate groups, probably as SO<ce:inf loc="post">2.</ce:inf>
</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is excited by wavelengths longer than 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> ions; Ce<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The two kinds of emission shown by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have different lifetimes. In the inset of , the lifetime distributions determined by fitting the emission decay kinetics through the Maximum Entropy method  are displayed. The CT band has a broad distribution of lifetimes ranging from tens up to tenths of nanoseconds with three main peaks at 10.3, 3.7 and 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns, in agreement with the three-exponential function used to fit the luminescence decay through the least-squared analysis. On the other hand, the emission due to the diphosphonic ligand has a more restricted distribution of lifetimes, of biexponential character with two peaks at 0.4 and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns as lifetimes, in agreement with the least-squared analysis .</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">
<ce:italic>Analysis</ce:italic> CeNC<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>PSH<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf> requires Ce 28.7%, P 6.3%, S 6.5%. Found Ce 31.3%, P 6.4%, S 6.7%. IR (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) 3438 (s), 3015(w), 2751(w), 1640(m), 1298(m), 1124(s), 1030(s), 614(m)</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para view="all">
<ce:italic>Crystal data and refinement detail for</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: Empirical formula C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>CeNO<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>PSH<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>; formula weight 484.22, triclinic <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>, <ce:sup loc="pre">d</ce:sup>GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.44</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
The thermal behavior of 1 has been studied by coupling thermogravimetric and thermodiffractometric analyses.

The coupled TG-DTA analysis (see S.I.) shows that compound 1, dried for 3 days over 75 R.H. NaCl, loses all the water molecules in the range 25-150°C. The initial weight loss (14.3%) can be ascribed to the loss of the eight water molecules (calc. 14.8%)

A plateau is then observed between 170 and 320°C and it should correspond to the formation of the anhydrous phase.

Between 320 and 500°C a second weight loss (calc. 21.3%, obs. 22%) is observed and it corresponds to the combustion of the organic part. The third weight loss of about 7% is observed in 650-780°C temperature range and it should correspond to the sublimation of the sulfate groups, probably as SO2. 

The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320°C.

Compound 1, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in   (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with λ <300nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If 1 is excited by wavelengths longer than 300nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for 1, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce4+ ions; Ce3+ ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138cm-1) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480cm-1) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).

The two kinds of emission shown by 1 have different lifetimes. In the inset of , the lifetime distributions determined by fitting the emission decay kinetics through the Maximum Entropy method  are displayed. The CT band has a broad distribution of lifetimes ranging from tens up to tenths of nanoseconds with three main peaks at 10.3, 3.7 and 0.15ns, in agreement with the three-exponential function used to fit the luminescence decay through the least-squared analysis. On the other hand, the emission due to the diphosphonic ligand has a more restricted distribution of lifetimes, of biexponential character with two peaks at 0.4 and 2ns as lifetimes, in agreement with the least-squared analysis .

 Analysis CeNC6O9PSH19 requires Ce 28.7%, P 6.3%, S 6.5%. Found Ce 31.3%, P 6.4%, S 6.7%. IR (ν max/cm-1) 3438 (s), 3015(w), 2751(w), 1640(m), 1298(m), 1124(s), 1030(s), 614(m)

 Crystal data and refinement detail for 1: Empirical formula C6CeNO12PSH19; formula weight 484.22, triclinic   P   1   ¯    , a  = 7.3087(7), b =14.564(1), c =6.8079(7)Å, α =91.60(1)°, β  = 93.72(1)°, γ =78.15(1)°, V =707.66(9)Å3, Z =2, calculated density 2.03gcm-3; no. of data=5611, no. of reflections=3072; no. of variables=83; no. of restraints=42 a Rp   = 0.0611, b Rwp   = 0.0825,      c     R     F   2     = 0.128  , dGOF=2.44

metadata.title: A new dual luminescent pillared cerium(IV)sulfate–diphosphonate
